newsitem.title: COLOMBIA: Colombia finance says loan offer may not be viable.
newsitem.headline: Colombia finance says loan offer may not be viable.

text.p: A senior Colombian Finance Ministry official said the ministry has not yet been notified of an offer of $3 billion in financing from Japan's Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi Ltd and the offer may not be fully viable.
A statement from the Ministry of Mines and Energy said the offer was made Thursday during talks in Tokyo between senior bank officials and Mines and Energy Minister Rodrigo Villamizar.
But Clemente del Valle, the Finance Ministry's head of Public Credit, said he had not been notified of the loan offer and stressed that there had been no official agreement to accept it.
"It's possible that some components of the offer will be looked at," Del Valle told Reuters in a telephone interview. "But I don't see a $3 billion package as viable," he said.

The statement from the Ministry of Mines and Energy said the $3 billion had been tentatively earmarked to help finance the state oil company Ecopetrol's exploration of the sprawling Piedemonte oil and gas field in Coolombia's eastern plains.
It would also be used to help finance construction of the Oleoducto Central SA (Ocensa) pipeline, which willl link the giant Cusiana and Cupiagua oil fields with the Caribbean port of Covenas.

Some of the funds would also be used to cover the financing needs of Emcali, the state-run telephone company in Colombia's southwest city of Cali, and to shore up finances at Colombia's foreign trade bank, known by its Spanish-language acronym as Bancoldex, the Mines and Energy Ministry statement said.
It was not immediately clear why the statement had been issued without being cleared first by the Finance Ministry, which is the only government body authorized to approve new public sector credits.
